title: Halloweentown High
descriptions:
Halloweentown High (2004) follows teenage witch Marnie Piper as she pushes to bridge the gap between her magical hometown and the mortal world. Having previously helped open a portal between Halloweentown and Earth, Marnie is convinced that peaceful coexistence is possible. To prove it, she proposes an exchange program that brings several Halloweentown students—each with their own supernatural identity—into her human high school, disguised by magic as ordinary teens. Confident but impulsive, Marnie stakes the Cromwell family’s magical heirlooms and power as a guarantee that nothing will go wrong, a bold pledge that alarms her cautious grandmother, Aggie.

Marnie and Aggie work together as chaperones and mentors. Aggie takes a job at the school, awkwardly navigating mortal customs while watching over the students. The exchange group includes a werewolf, a troll, an ogre, and others whose disguised appearances mask their true forms. While the students try to blend in—joining clubs, trying out for activities, and making friends—mysterious incidents begin to occur: threatening graffiti appears, ominous symbols are found, and a sense of danger keeps building. Marnie suspects an extremist anti-magic faction known as the Knights of the Iron Dagger, a secretive order long rumored to oppose the magical community.

At school, Marnie also develops a connection with a new boy, Ethan, whose friendly demeanor and curiosity make him an ally, though his background turns out to be complicated. Meanwhile, the principal, Phil Flanagan, seems supportive yet skeptical, and a new social studies teacher, Miss Periwinkle, urges tolerance and cultural exchange. As Halloweentown students face prejudice and fear, the tension mirrors the broader challenge of acceptance: learning to trust what’s different.

When a school mascot statue—a towering knight—is unveiled as the theme for the upcoming Halloween Carnival, the symbolism unnerves Marnie. She discovers that the Knights of the Iron Dagger may have infiltrated the school, using the carnival as a cover for a plan to unmask the exchange students and force the portal between worlds closed forever. Strange magical disturbances and targeted sabotage cause the human students to turn suspicious, and Marnie’s promise—her family’s magic—hangs in the balance.

Aggie’s spells begin to falter as she spreads herself thin maintaining the students’ disguises, and the exchange kids, tired of hiding, question whether Marnie’s idealism has put them all in danger. Marnie uncovers hints that the Knights once tried to destroy Halloweentown and that the order might be linked to someone at the school. As she pieces together the mystery, she learns that Ethan’s father, a warlock named Edgar Dalloway, is involved in the scheme. Pretending to support integration, he manipulates events to prove that magical creatures and humans can’t coexist, intending to seize power when fear is at its highest.

On the night of the Halloween Carnival, the plan comes to a head. The knights use enchanted steel and a trap woven into the knight statue to reveal the exchange students’ true forms, hoping to turn the crowd against them. Panic starts to spread, and Marnie’s wager on her family’s magic is on the brink of being lost. Summoning her courage and leadership, Marnie addresses her classmates and neighbors, urging them to see the students for who they are rather than what they look like. Her mortal friends step up, defending the exchange group, and the tide turns as people refuse to give in to fear.

Aggie, Marnie, and the students work together to neutralize the spell and disarm the knights. Ethan, rejecting his father’s fanaticism, helps Marnie expose Dalloway’s plot. The crowd’s acceptance robs the knights of their power, and the barriers between worlds—once controlled by suspicion and secrecy—give way to trust. Marnie’s gamble pays off: the Cromwell magic is preserved, the exchange program survives, and the possibility of lasting peace grows stronger.

In the aftermath, the school community embraces diversity more openly, Aggie becomes a beloved if eccentric figure on campus, and Marnie—still learning—gains a deeper appreciation for responsibility. Halloweentown and the mortal world step closer together, proving that tradition and change can coexist when people choose understanding over fear.
